Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit


Peter,

Some organisms are synchronized colonies of specialized single cell
organisms e.g. sponges, certain jellyfish. I believe it correct to say
multicellular species have taken this synchronization to a more fundamental
level - genetic integration.  

Ken Lloyd


        From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf
Of petar_chervenski
        Sent: Saturday, January 05, 2008 4:08 PM
        To: neat@yahoogroups.com
        Subject: [neat] The first stages of evolutionary complexification?
       
       

        Hi all.
       
        This topic is more of a biological issue, but it involves
        complexification. It is about how it all started.
       
        Well, we all assume that everything started with single-cell
        organisms like the amoeba and the bacteria. So, these cells were
        living a nice life but suddenly colonies appeared. Many single-cell
        organisms living together. We also assume that the multi-cell
        organisms (like us) have evolved from such colonies.
       
        But how this happened? Some bacteria mutated and added a new gene
        that guided it to form groups with the other ones? It is really
        interesting. In order to understand the underlying mechanisms of
        complexification in nature, we should know how this happened.
       
        I don't think that just a single new gene can tell the cell to form
        complex relationships with others. Perhaps I am wrong, but since we
        know that the organisms at present time evolved via
complexification,
        the answer to the question of "what was the genetic change that
        turned single-cell organisms into multi-cell organisms" is
essential.
       
        Besides, there is something that can even break the evolution
theory.
        An example is the bacteria's propeller tail. It is a very complex
        mechanism composed of many parts depending on each other. How did
        this evolve? What was that gene appearance? This just cannot evolve
        gradually, it is a "jump" in evolution. I know that the populations
        get separated into species within their own niches but the quiestion
        of how this evolved is not answered yet.
       
        Peter
       
       

        




------=_NextPart_000_008A_01C84FBC.64597790
